title: How many US adult and pediatric hospital admissions with confirmed COVID-19 cases will there be for the week ending 1 May 2021?
preds:
So hospital admissions for 5 days ~ 25,300- with 2 more days to go. It seems like a touch & go and yet the consensus seems to be converging on 35-45.  Here is what I know  a) Retroactive adjustments are likely- mostly because of a delay in reporting and these are likely to add to the numbers.
b) Cases are falling, at least 15% in the last 2 weeks. This ought to translate into lower hospitalizations  i.e. of course we should expect decreases in hospital admissions that will be lower than case decrease.
c) This is a weird one- could easily trip me up. Hospital admissions are lower on the weekends- that just seems to be empirically true and not just an artifact of reporting.  Would that mean, we should see lower numbers for the balance of days? May be. (a) is a blackbox, at least the backlog if it exists, shouldn't be significant- unlike the vaccinations. (b) is true on average, very hard to be conclusive about *this* particular week. (c) is interesting enough to increase my probability for 35-45 bucket and likely will make me regret later. What was I thinking?
Changing forecast to reflect current information

I assume 1 week to deadline.   I assume hospitalizations are going down exponentially.  There are currently 27692 cases.  If it rises slightly, it will be there.  If it falls slightly, it will reach that value.  If it remains constant, it will be at that value.  It's been dropping for a while, and appears to again be dropping.
Changing forecast based on updated information

Looks like it may have peaked and is coming back down. 38.7k as of 4/23/21. Would have to drop by about 460 hospitalizations a day to fall under 35k. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZcBUiyKRnqhppa6yb2FFmRexYO6bOELvRCzMk7DZGd8/edit?usp=sharing
According to Google Spreadsheet by @RyanBeck, (thank you), the total was 40,289 as of 4/17/21.
falling rate of hospitalizations + effect of vaccinations kicking in
Adjusting forecast due to passage of time
A certain demographic resistance to prevention guidelines.

Hospitalizations still rising, up to 40,000 as of latest release. Increasing 35 to 45 to most likely. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZcBUiyKRnqhppa6yb2FFmRexYO6bOELvRCzMk7DZGd8/edit?usp=sharing

Found a better source which lists a more complete data series.  (Hey America: your data reporting sucks!)  Anyway, it said hospitalizations were trending downward, with an observed plateau in recent months (likely what I observed).  This plateau increased for a time, before it began to take a plunge in the last two days.  (Two day data series are inaccurate.)  In short, including my two other prediction rationales, (hospitalization drops by vaccines cancelled out by increased human contact as people begin to socialize again,) and including decreases due to the arrival of spring, I assume this result.  However, a lower result could be justified with the fact that hospitalizations trend ahead of the 7 day average.
The numbers going down directly and there are more and more people with are vaccinated. So I believe in that the numbers are down extremly on 1st may and als I expect it.

Right now the cases are trending between 4-6K per day. There will be an uptick due to vacation, especially related to school-aged kids’ Spring Break, and some states reopening. Ultimately, unless there is a new variant that evades the vaccine or something unforeseen, because vaccines and the weather warming, I expect the cases to remain about where they are now (early April) with a slight uptick as those that traveled and the people they come into unsafe contact find out they were exposed and transmit it when they return home due to the symptomatic latency period of 3-7 days.

Up to 36.6k as of April 3. I think there's a good chance elderly vaccinations help this steadily decrease, but there's also a decent chance cases fluctuate over the coming month so I'm distributing up and down a bit while putting a bit more weight on down. Data and plot here (if this doesn't load try a different browser, I've occasionally had issues on chrome but it usually loads okay on Edge): https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZcBUiyKRnqhppa6yb2FFmRexYO6bOELvRCzMk7DZGd8/edit?usp=sharing

Again, absent an exogenous disaster -- China, Mexican border, Mideast, Virus 2.0 and 3.0 -- and the immediacy of the calendar, I posit a first approximation based on abstractly smooth curves, heading for a happy ending.
I looked at the question again.  Realized that May 1 is effectively "tomorrow."

I have not paid sustained attention to the data.  Not my subject.  Therefore, for me it's a question requiring strategic abstraction. Seems to me I need to identify macro factors and propose their direction.  I may well have the magnitudes wrong, but what I'm trying to posit is a general decline, as the spread burns itself out with -- yes -- herd immunity, the elimination of many potential carriers among the elderly, greater public awareness and most of all the vaccines.As for my "methodology," It would improve a lot with a couple of data points.  My suppositions indeed are too abstract, but they won't be for long.  On the other hand, wild cards -- Virus 2.0 -- would upset analyses badly and make severe and sudden demands on leaders. doctors, public safety . . .
